instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00164: What is 820-00164? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light yes fan no
threads.message:
hey everyone,
have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that gave a brief display, and fan, then no fan and a sim green/orange light. <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> was messed up, so I changed it out, seems to have fixed the dim mag safe light. Also changed burned components around <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN</SIGNAL>.  Have <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> but no pp5v_ s4rs3 or S0. Any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light yes fan no
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> at L7560? Resistors around SPI ROM? Pulsing <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>, check with scope.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light yes fan no
threads.message: <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is present. At L7560. Resistors around SPI are Ok. Only thing that was visibly corroded after replacing the lcdbklt area, was one probe point opposite the <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN</SIGNAL> area. It's completely burnt and gone. Could this be the cause? Also, scope is effed up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light yes fan no
threads.message:
Anything going on at L7520? Could be short pulsing...
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin 8 is of course also a prime suspect and crap around <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light yes fan no
threads.message: Dead at L7520, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> has voltage at pin 8, looks like <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> enable pin is not being "enabled". <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> has voltage and looks fine around it. The burnt probe point is 1123 on the <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_DIV_L</SIGNAL> net. Think that would have a weird tie to it some how?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light yes fan no
threads.message: What is PPBUS voltage? Voltages on <RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR>/01/02/03?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light yes fan no
threads.message:
At f7700- 8.6v
<RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR>-3- 3.42

so weird and feel like it's just at the tip of my fingers.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light yes fan no
threads.message: Also 17.01 all along the dcin circuit. Is this low? Should it be around 18?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light yes fan no
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light yes fan no
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is reading 3.42v I can't remember if this is what it should read with the board out.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light yes fan no
threads.message: 3v at pin 8 of <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>? J6100 checked and/or removed? <SIGNAL>SUS_EN</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light yes fan no
threads.message: 3.42 at pin 8 of <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>, j6100 I removed before posting original question. Just to be safe. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is reading 3.34. Could it be the bios? If so, would one from a 3437 work on this board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light yes fan no
threads.message:
BIOS will be fine...
Check if <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> is not pulsing, can be very hard to catch on a multimeter, scope is best.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light yes fan no
threads.message:
No Title

Having some issues dialing in the scope. It doesn't appear to to register but my scales could be out of whack and they're not adjusting right.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light yes fan no
threads.message: 1v/div vertical and 10ms/div horizontal should show something.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light yes fan no
threads.message: That's what I was afraid of. Nothing, no reading. I will say though, as an anomoly, the fan just started spinning for the first time for about 10 seconds... does that mean anything?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light yes fan no
threads.message: Corrosion under SMC maybe? <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>? Could be so many things....
